abstract.p: In an adverse selection context, this article explores the relative usefulness of price information over quantity information. The main finding is that price monitoring can induce a sales level that is greater than the full‐information sales level. This imposes additional selling costs on the agent and reduces that agent’s rents. The analysis identifies sufficient conditions for the principal to prefer price monitoring over quantity monitoring. Business‐format franchises exhibit many of the features of the setting analyzed here, and the article's findings have implications for designing information systems in that sector of the economy.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The U.S. Commerce Department estimates that business investment in information systems (IS) and information technology (IT) equipment has more than doubled from about $243 billion in 1995 to about $510 billion in 1999(Digital economy 2000). Such investments are improving the tracking of heretofore unobservable business transactions between firms and between firms and consumers.1While data availability is useful, the key to success in many instances lies elsewhere; as Deshpande (2001, 4) points out, the “advantage lies not in merely possessing current market information but in knowing how to use it.”

In practice, many firms approach information systems planning by identifying the IT department’s desired technical requirements (e.g., open systems, client/server, or real time). Often, the IS/IT department and the business groups in an organization do not communicate efficiently with each other (Cassidy1998). The end result can be an investment of millions of dollars without much return. In discussing the best practices in information technology, Cortada (1997, xv), for instance, observes that chief information officers and chief executive officers routinely lose sleep contemplating, “[I am] not sure I am getting real value for my IT investment.”

With few exceptions (see, e.g., Wierenga, van Bruggen, and Staelin1999), the marketing literature rarely mentions IS/IT and has not devoted much attention to comparing the value of different pieces of information. The purpose here is to take a step toward bridging this gap in the literature. Using a mathematical model, this article explores the relative value of two pieces of basic marketing information, price and quantity sold, in managing business relationships.

More specifically, the analysis focuses on market settings that have the following four characteristics. (1) First, three parties are involved: one is the buyer, such as a consumer obtaining auto maintenance service in a retail establishment; the next is a seller, such as a business‐format franchisee that provides the service to the buyers; and the last is a third party, such as a business‐format franchisor that has a vested interest in how the seller interacts with the buyers. (2) The local market conditions experienced by the seller (such as the demand conditions for an automotive repair shop, e.g., Meineke, in the downtown area) are not easily observed by the third party. In other words, the seller has better information about the intensity of demand than the third party. (3) Further, the third party cannot observe the transaction between a buyer and the seller without the help of an appropriate (and expensive) interorganizational information system. (4) The terms of the transaction between the buyer and the seller affect the amount of gain enjoyed by the third party. Consequently, the third party has an incentive to influence the seller’s terms of sale; at the same time, the seller has an incentive to exploit its informational advantage.

In settings characterized by the above four features, information clearly has a strategic value. Therefore, the third‐party IS/IT planner stands to gain by understanding the relative value of different pieces of information in the transaction between the buyers and the seller.2It is worth noting that the four market characteristics identified above arise in a wide variety of business‐format franchise settings. Business format franchising is pervasive in the U.S. economy and accounts for roughly 460 billion dollars, or 9.5%, of all private sector output (PriceWaterhouseCoopers2004).3The lines of business operating under this format of franchising include automotive maintenance services, commercial and residential services, full‐service restaurants, business services, and personal services.4

The primary issue being examined here is whether price information offers any differential strategic advantage over quantity information.5Since firms here cope with differential informational advantage, the agency theory framework is appropriate for the analysis. The connection between the current study and the extant literature is now discussed.

Over the past 2 decades or so, researchers in marketing explored various types of incentives that assist in managing sales forces and distribution channels (see, e.g., Basu et al.1985; Desai and Srinivasan1995; Joseph and Thevaranjan1998; Desiraju2004). While incentives are often linked to the sales generated by an agent, this stream of research includes studies in which the price authority is delegated to an agent (see, e.g., Lal1986; Bharadwaj2001; Joseph2001); further, other investigations in this stream focus on adverse selection settings and mechanism design (see, e.g., Lal and Staelin1986; Rao1990; Chu1992; Desiraju and Moorthy1997). The current analysis, too, examines an adverse selection setting. In addition, this article explicitly compares price‐based contracts with quantity‐based contracts and, in that sense, extends the principal‐agent analyses in marketing.

In the economics literature, there are two sets of research studies that are relevant here. In the first set, Weitzman (1974) pioneered comparing the value of quantities and prices as possible planning instruments in controlling a central economy. Since then, employing his framework, economists have compared prices and quantities in contexts as varied as politics (Finkelshtain and Kislev1997), fisheries (Jensen and Vestergaard2003), and environmental pollution (Montero2002; Moledina et al.2003). This set of studies, however, does not focus on mechanism design in adverse selection settings as does the second set of studies (see e.g., Lewis and Sappington1988; Tirole1988, 176–77; Armstrong and Sappington2005). However, in this latter stream of research, no attention has been devoted to exploring the relative effectiveness of price‐based and quantity‐based contracts. Therefore, by explicitly comparing the two types of contracts in an adverse selection context, the current analysis complements the extant literature in both economics and marketing.

As a precursor to what will follow, recall that in standard adverse selection contracts, except in the most productive state of nature, the principal stipulates that the agent should sell less than the full‐information quantity. The analysis will show that under price monitoring, the principal can induce the agent to sell more than the full‐information quantity. The higher quantity imposes higher selling costs on the agent and has the potential to reduce his informational rents significantly. This article identifies sufficient conditions for the principal to prefer price monitoring over quantity monitoring. With these issues in mind, the rest of the article is organized as follows.Section IIpresents the basic model.Section IIIdevelops the optimal contracts and compares a price‐monitoring regime with the corresponding quantity‐monitoring regime.Section IVconcludes the article with directions for further work. All proofs are confined to anappendix.

fn.p: Marketing researchers have long noted that expensive information systems may be necessary to observe accurately both marketing inputs, such as a sales force’s actions, and the outputs resulting from such inputs (see, e.g., Anderson and Oliver1987).
In the remainder of the article, for expositional ease, the third party (e.g., the franchisor) is referred to as the principal, and the seller (the franchisee) as the agent.

In contrast, in product distribution franchising (which includes auto and truck dealers, gasoline service stations, and beverage bottling as the main lines of business), the output is roughly one‐third of that in business format franchising.

These franchisors, as a class, use a variety of contracts in which franchisee payments are contingent on different variables (see, e.g., Desai1997). The International Franchise Association reports that the payments are sometimes contingent on revenues, sometimes on margins, and at other times on the number of transactions (e.g., a royalty fee based on a per transaction charge—such as on a per car rental). However, researchers have not focused on understanding the possible reasons for that variation.
In what follows, the regime with a price information system will be referred to as price monitoring, and the regime with a unit sales information system as quantity monitoring.

sec.title: The Model
sec.p: In this benchmark case, the optimal price in each state of nature is selected so that the marginal benefit and marginal cost are exactly equal; as is evident from lemma 1, these optimal prices are strictly greater than marginal costs.11Further, the principal optimally extracts all of the agent’s surplus through the transfer payment.

fn.p: These can include costs of service provision or incidental selling costs.
This assumption makes it easier to compare the two monitoring regimes. The main intuition in the analysis, however, will apply to alternative model formulations.

Rationing by the agent is not allowed in this analysis. Thanks are due to an anonymous referee for noting that the results reported here may be modified suitably when the agent is allowed to employ rationing. That analysis is beyond the scope of this article.

The assumption of (weakly) increasing marginal selling cost is reasonable in settings where firms operate relatively close to, but below, the fixed capacity, such as in many business‐format franchisee operations.

This is in contrast to the analysis in Lewis and Sappington (1988) and Armstrong and Sappington (2005), where a social welfare maximizing regulator can impose marginal cost pricing on the firm. In the current analysis, the principal and agent do not take social welfare into account. Consequently, marginal cost pricing is not feasible, and the results in this article differ from those in Lewis and Sappington (1988) and Armstrong and Sappington (2005).

sec.title: Optimal Monitoring System
sec.p: The intuition for these results follows from the discussion following lemmas 2, 3, and 5. Essentially, under quantity monitoring, by understating demand, the agent enjoys revenues from the higher price that can be set in the market. Under price monitoring, too, when the agent understates demand, there is a gain from the extra sales that are generated. These extra sales, however, come at a cost to the agent. Consequently, as lemmas 2 and 5 indicate, the principal will prefer price monitoring either when marginal costs are increasing at a sufficiently steep rate or when the demand curves do not shift too far apart with θ.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Firms are investing in information systems and information technology more than ever before. These investments are making it possible for firms to have access to business transaction data that have traditionally been difficult to obtain. In that context, assessing the relative strategic value of different pieces of information is useful and will play a key role in costly information system design.

Using the agency theory framework, this article explored the usefulness of price versus quantity information. The main finding is that price monitoring can induce a sales level that is greater than the full‐information sales level. That higher level imposes additional selling costs on the agent and serves to reduce that agent’s informational rents. This feature favors the principal’s optimal contracts being contingent on the agent’s price rather than on the units sold to customers. The mathematical analysis here identifies sufficient conditions under which price monitoring dominates quantity monitoring; two factors, marginal costs that increase sufficiently steeply and demand curves that do not shift too far apart with exogenous shocks, favor the use of price monitoring.

Business‐format franchises exhibit many of the features of the setting analyzed here, and the article’s analysis has implications for designing information systems for that sector of the economy. It is worth noting that the model in this article considered only discrete states of nature; in addition, the characterization of monitoring discussed here is clearly a special case of a broader class of agency problems. Therefore, more general investigations, such as those allowing the agent to employ rationing, on the relative merits of different monitoring regimes deserve attention. Overall, this article highlights the significance of understanding the relative value of different pieces of market information. It is hoped that the analysis here will spark further work in this important area of research.
